title: Autoregressive Image Generation Guided by Chains of Thought
author: Miaomiao Cai (University of Science and Technology of China), Guanjie Wang (University of Science and Technology of China), Wei Li (Huawei Noah's Ark Lab), Zhijun Tu (Huawei Noah's Ark Lab), Hanting Chen (Huawei Noah's Ark Lab), Shaohui Lin (East China Normal University), Jie Hu (Huawei Noah's Ark Lab), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces innovative reasoning prompts which could inform similar strategies in audio processing tasks, enabling more robust contextual understanding and generation in Haohe Liu's audio-related work.
background: This paper focuses on enhancing autoregressive image generation through reasoning prompts that guide the generation process, simulating human-like reasoning to improve image quality and coherence.
contribution: This paper introduces Image Generation with Thoughtful Reasoning (IGTR) to solve issues related to contextual coherence in autoregressive image generation, achieving approximately 20% improvement in image quality metrics.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing autoregressive methods struggle with effectively reconstructing images and often lack structured reasoning capabilities.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by incorporating reasoning prompts that allow the model to consider overall image distribution before generating details, enhancing both accuracy and stability.

key_innovation: Utilizes specialized reasoning prompts to simulate human reasoning processes during image generation, improving the ability to handle complex visuals.
real_world_impact: By improving image generation quality, the method can be applied in various creative fields including advertising, entertainment, and virtual reality applications, enhancing user experiences with high-quality generated visuals.

new_terms.Chain-of-Thought prompting: **Chain-of-Thought prompting** is a technique that encourages models to generate intermediate reasoning steps to improve performance on complex tasks by simulating logical reasoning processes.
